commit_message:
puppet/syntax: do not export FUTURE_PARSER when Puppet > 3

FUTURE_PARSER environment variable has no meaning any more from Puppet
4.

If you try to activate it in Puppet4, you'll have this error:
Attempt to assign a value to unknown setting :parser

Change-Id: I04d727842a9bd7e45cdbbdff99182dd8ef83c06c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/82/198382/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # FUTURE_PARSER=yes is only supported by Puppet 3.x if [ "{puppet_version}" -lt "4" ]; then export FUTURE_PARSER=yes fi

commit_message:
Fix unit tests

- Updated script to improve functionality (see --help)
- Disabled unit tests for:
  - 'apache' they are broken in 1.2.0
  - 'ceilometer' rspec does not work in 4.0.0
  - 'firewall' rspec does not work in 1.0.2
  - 'horizon' rspec does not work in 5.0.0
  - 'memcached' rspec does not work in 2.5.0
  - 'monit' rspec does not work in 0.0.4
  - 'ntp' rspec does not work in 3.3.0
  - 'rabbitmq' rspec does not work in 5.5.0

Fuel-CI is disabled because this patch does not affect deployment,
so integration testing is not needed.

Partial-bug: #1455847
Fuel-CI: disable
Change-Id: I608ad6057ab3ef9c924c5b7b832f7c119b8f6b2a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/25/195625/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: usage="$(basename "$0") [-h] [-m MODULE] [-a] -- runs unit tests for puppet modules, by default runs tests only for changed modules. where: -h show this help text -a|--all run unit tests for all modules -m|--module MODULE run unit tests for specified module " while [[ $# > 0 ]] ; do key="$1" case $key in -a|--all) ALL='1' ;; -m|--modules) MODULES="$MODULES $2" shift # past argument ;; -h|--help) echo "$usage" >&2 exit 0 ;; *) # unknown option ;; esac shift # past argument or value done if [ "$ALL" == '1' ] ; then modules=`ls -d $WORKSPACE/deployment/puppet/*` elif ! [ -z "$MODULES" ] ; then modules=$MODULES else git diff --name-only HEAD~ &>/dev/null || exit 1 modules=$(git diff --name-only HEAD~ | grep -o 'deployment/puppet/[^/]*/' | sort -u) fi echo "Checking modules: $modules"
deleted_lines: modules=$(git diff --name-only HEAD~ | grep -o 'deployment/puppet/[^/]*/' | sort -u) git diff --name-only HEAD~ &>/dev/null || exit 1

commit_message:
pass baymodel date instead of bay data for baymodel create request

This patch just uses the correct request parameters for baymodel when
policy enforce the baymodel post method.

Acutally, without this patch, the testcase still can work.

Anyway, it is better to be more rigorous.

Change-Id: I95836b8370f13a8945be358a2ad663dcc7056d28
Closes-Bug: #1471074

commit_message:
Adds MonitorMetricTypeField enum field

Preparation for cleanup of the nova.compute.monitors modules to use a
versioned object interface. Here we add a new enum derivative field that
contains the current string keys used for metric "names" that the
compute monitors return in the get_metrics() calls. This allows us to
standardize these metric key names.

Change-Id: I47d3ed2d3c0f6a3c33eaa9539d38aaff2f4df573
Partial-bug: 1466929

commit_message:
Add documentation about the usage of api-no-pipline

This feature has implemented a different mechanism when posting samples
via API, the related configuration and API usage (a bit different than
before) should be described in doc.

Partially implements: blueprint api-no-pipeline

Change-Id: I8e29aab749aba6754b8dca4356bc0e44c673b9a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/09/195409/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: By default, samples posted via API will be putted into notification bus, and ceilometer-agent-notification will receive the samples and publish it by publisher(s) which is configured in pipeline.yaml, meanwhile, the samples will be filtered and transformed by sample pipeline (if samples match the pipeline definition). Then, if the publisher is MessagingPublisher or UDPPublisher, ceilometer-collector will receive the samples from notification-agent and dispatch it to storage backend, otherwise, samples will be published to other receivers. In this way, the post_samples API depends on the notification-agent service, and the 'notification_driver' need to be configured in ceilometer.conf, like this:: notification_driver = messagingv2 Another way, samples posted via API can also be putted into storage backend directly by specifying a boolean flag 'direct' in the request URL, like this:: POST /v2/meters/ram_util?direct=True In this way, the post_samples API doesn't depend on notification-agent service and doesn't need the 'notification_driver' configuration, the weak point is that samples will skip the pipeline definition (no supporting check and no transformation). This way is mainly used for testing.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/68/198268/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_utils import encodeutilsfrom heat.common.i18n import _LWLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) ret[res.key] = _decrypt(res.value, res.decrypt_method) return _decrypt(result.value, result.decrypt_method)def _encrypt(value): if value is not None: return crypt.encrypt(value.encode('utf-8')) else: return None, None def _decrypt(enc_value, method): if method is None: return None decryptor = getattr(crypt, method) value = decryptor(enc_value) if value is not None: return six.text_type(value, 'utf-8') method, value = _encrypt(value) method, trust_id = _encrypt(values.get('trust_id')) method, password = _encrypt(values['password']) result['password'] = _decrypt(result['password'], db_result.decrypt_method) result['trust_id'] = _decrypt(result['trust_id'], db_result.decrypt_method) encoded_val = encodeutils.safe_encode(param_val) encrypted_val = crypt.encrypt(encoded_val, encryption_key) decrypt_function_name = parameters[param_name][0] decrypt_function = getattr(crypt, decrypt_function_name) decrypted_val = decrypt_function(parameters[param_name][1], encryption_key) try: parameters[param_name] = encodeutils.safe_decode( decrypted_val) except UnicodeDecodeError as ex: # if the incorrect encryption_key was used then we can get # total gibberish here and safe_decode() will freak out. LOG.warn(_LW("Couldn't decrypt parameters %s"), ex) parameters[param_name] = ""
deleted_lines: ret[res.key] = crypt.decrypt(res.decrypt_method, res.value) return crypt.decrypt(result.decrypt_method, result.value) method, value = crypt.encrypt(value) method, trust_id = crypt.encrypt(values.get('trust_id')) method, password = crypt.encrypt(values['password']) result['password'] = crypt.decrypt( db_result.decrypt_method, result['password']) result['trust_id'] = crypt.decrypt( db_result.decrypt_method, result['trust_id']) encrypted_val = crypt.encrypt(param_val, encryption_key) method, value = parameters[param_name] decrypted_val = crypt.decrypt(method, value, encryption_key) parameters[param_name] = decrypted_val

commit_message:
add python-scciclient version number requirement

The current driver-requirements.txt has no version number requirement
for python-scciclient.
This patch adds the required python-scciclient version number in
driver-requirements.txt for the iRMC Power and Management modules.

Change-Id: Icaf621c442b60fb1f480d715a40f4929c4a4e929

commit_message:
Skip OSTF results that are not belong to running test_sets

To check just necessary test sets, results for other test sets
should be skipped.

Change-Id: I366d289664c9a50ede9359bda95a09f33e58c61e
Closes-Bug:#1468682

commit_message:
Switch to oslo.service

oslo.service has graduated, so murano should consume it.

Change-Id: I820a56920c1583d57880acf7d21fbd4a296ca26e
Closes-Bug: #1466851

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2012 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import threading import eventlet from eventlet import greenpool from muranoagent.openstack.common import log as logging from muranoagent.openstack.common import loopingcall LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def _thread_done(gt, *args, **kwargs): """Callback function to be passed to GreenThread.link() when we spawn() Calls the :class:`ThreadGroup` to notify if. """ kwargs['group'].thread_done(kwargs['thread']) class Thread(object): """Wrapper around a greenthread, that holds a reference to the :class:`ThreadGroup`. The Thread will notify the :class:`ThreadGroup` when it has done so it can be removed from the threads list. """ def __init__(self, thread, group): self.thread = thread self.thread.link(_thread_done, group=group, thread=self) def stop(self): self.thread.kill() def wait(self): return self.thread.wait() def link(self, func, *args, **kwargs): self.thread.link(func, *args, **kwargs) class ThreadGroup(object): """The point of the ThreadGroup class is to: * keep track of timers and greenthreads (making it easier to stop them when need be). * provide an easy API to add timers. """ def __init__(self, thread_pool_size=10): self.pool = greenpool.GreenPool(thread_pool_size) self.threads = [] self.timers = [] def add_dynamic_timer(self, callback, initial_delay=None, periodic_interval_max=None, *args, **kwargs): timer = loopingcall.DynamicLoopingCall(callback, *args, **kwargs) timer.start(initial_delay=initial_delay, periodic_interval_max=periodic_interval_max) self.timers.append(timer) def add_timer(self, interval, callback, initial_delay=None, *args, **kwargs): pulse = loopingcall.FixedIntervalLoopingCall(callback, *args, **kwargs) pulse.start(interval=interval, initial_delay=initial_delay) self.timers.append(pulse) def add_thread(self, callback, *args, **kwargs): gt = self.pool.spawn(callback, *args, **kwargs) th = Thread(gt, self) self.threads.append(th) return th def thread_done(self, thread): self.threads.remove(thread) def _stop_threads(self): current = threading.current_thread() # Iterate over a copy of self.threads so thread_done doesn't # modify the list while we're iterating for x in self.threads[:]: if x is current: # don't kill the current thread. continue try: x.stop() except Exception as ex: LOG.exception(ex) def stop_timers(self): for x in self.timers: try: x.stop() except Exception as ex: LOG.exception(ex) self.timers = [] def stop(self, graceful=False): """stop function has the option of graceful=True/False. * In case of graceful=True, wait for all threads to be finished. Never kill threads. * In case of graceful=False, kill threads immediately. """ self.stop_timers() if graceful: # In case of graceful=True, wait for all threads to be # finished, never kill threads self.wait() else: # In case of graceful=False(Default), kill threads # immediately self._stop_threads() def wait(self): for x in self.timers: try: x.wait() except eventlet.greenlet.GreenletExit: pass except Exception as ex: LOG.exception(ex) current = threading.current_thread() # Iterate over a copy of self.threads so thread_done doesn't # modify the list while we're iterating for x in self.threads[:]: if x is current: continue try: x.wait() except eventlet.greenlet.GreenletExit: pass except Exception as ex: LOG.exception(ex)

commit_message:
puppet: do not run beaker/upgrade jobs on old branches

Beaker has been introduced after stable/juno, there is no need to run
the jobs before.

Change-Id: I482a82d0222224849d8d07916ba8ec5e1276c2e0

commit_message:
Fix tox -e py34

Use a whitelist of tests known to pass on Python 3. With a working
tox -e 34 command, it becomes possible to add a py34 non-voting gate,
and then make the py34 gate voting to avoid Python 3 regressions.

Remove the py33 test environment since OpenStack is now focused on
Python 3.4 (Python 3.3 is no more tested by the OpenStack infra).

Blueprint python3

Change-Id: I47677bc457bcabcd6432cad18b05b3f181ec49ab

commit_message:
Disable sahara scenarios from dsvm-rally

Sahara is disabled in gate-rally-dsvm-rally now.
This issue should be fixed in openstack-infra/project-config repo , but we
can speed up fix of gates and temporary disable sahara scenarios.

Change-Id: I7864c53ebed02f04bfdd3c5b66db26cb99271e6a

commit_message:
puppet: add puppet-unit-latest job

This non-voting job aims to run rspec tests without pining Puppet
version.
It will help us to see how behaves our modules with latest Puppet
release without breaking our CI.

Also, do not run this job in current stable branches because we only
supported Puppet < 4.0.

Change-Id: Id15e1a6d3b6210b73c0a2ae7750cfc5f0651f1f6

commit_message:
Upgrade version to Liberty!

Time to move on and synchronize with Liberty

Note: while transition to semver is planned, it doesn't seem
straightforward right now as pbr would complain about new version numbers.
Let's do it as a separate step later.

Change-Id: I719654963fe6f4bc27e05d39f233d2f697c25413

commit_message:
puppet: refactorize puppet-syntax job

Today we are running two kind of puppet-syntax jobs:
* Former puppet-syntax was useless because the same thing was running with
puppet-syntax-future.
* Former puppet-syntax-future were testing only Puppet 3.x release while
  Puppet 4 has been released.

This patch aims to:
* jenkins/jobs/macros.yaml: drop former puppet-syntax job
* jenkins/jobs/puppet-modules-jobs.yaml: rename puppet-syntax-future to puppet-syntax-{puppet_version} where
  we adapt the job to support both  Puppet 3.x and Puppet 4.x.
* jenkins/jobs/projects.yaml: drop useless gate-{name}-puppet-syntax-future since new puppet-syntax
  are part of puppet-check-jobs group.
* zuul/layout.yaml:
  * update puppet-syntax to use the new jobs
  * system-config: use new puppet-syntax jobs (old one is deleted)
  * puppet modules: drop useless puppet-syntax-future since it's part of puppet-check-jobs

Change-Id: I48320d361b0c22d088a0df7113a7a508de0f546d

subject: Use beaker-puppet_install_helper to install puppet
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-30 21:02:25.000000000', 'files': ['Gemfile', 'spec/spec_helper_acceptance.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer/commit/bf194d2f7593d769ea442959b90ec972cfb01c87', 'message': "Use beaker-puppet_install_helper to install puppet

When running with BEAKER_provision=no, the following happens:

In Trusty: beaker is running dpkg with '--force' option so even
if Puppet is already installed, the return code will be 0.
In CentOS: beaker is running 'rpm -ivh' the second time and since
the package is already here, the return code will be 1.

Using the new puppet install helper will abort installing puppet
if BEAKER_provision is no, so tests will continue as normal.

Change-Id: Ifeada55370bbd5b30418447c8fc1da101de2b774
Co-Authored-By: Colleen Murphy <colleen@gazlene.net>
"}]
commit_message:
Use beaker-puppet_install_helper to install puppet

When running with BEAKER_provision=no, the following happens:

In Trusty: beaker is running dpkg with '--force' option so even
if Puppet is already installed, the return code will be 0.
In CentOS: beaker is running 'rpm -ivh' the second time and since
the package is already here, the return code will be 1.

Using the new puppet install helper will abort installing puppet
if BEAKER_provision is no, so tests will continue as normal.

Change-Id: Ifeada55370bbd5b30418447c8fc1da101de2b774
Co-Authored-By: Colleen Murphy <colleen@gazlene.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer refs/changes/17/197317/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: hosts.each do |host| install_puppet on host, "mkdir -p #{host['distmoduledir']}" end

commit_message:
Hyper-V: checks for existent Notes in list_instance_notes

If there are VMs with Notes = None, the Hyper-V Driver cannot
start, as it tries to iterate over None, which results in an
exception.

This commit adds a check if the Notes exist, before iterating over
them.

Closes-Bug: #1438638

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/unit/virt/hyperv/test_vmutils.py
	nova/tests/unit/virt/hyperv/test_vmutilsv2.py

(cherry picked from commit 2c3da5462684c930436c9e91cb1e893e0936a331)

Change-Id: Icebdc03d7249fdf903b94b2f61f4891f5c9d6e50

commit_message:
Use beaker-puppet_install_helper to install puppet

When running with BEAKER_provision=no, the following happens:

In Trusty: beaker is running dpkg with '--force' option so even
if Puppet is already installed, the return code will be 0.
In CentOS: beaker is running 'rpm -ivh' the second time and since
the package is already here, the return code will be 1.

Using the new puppet install helper will abort installing puppet
if BEAKER_provision is no, so tests will continue as normal.

Change-Id: I0a1fb7df6bcc7deb611f37e12ecf8bc2f7a8c9dc
Co-Authored-By: Colleen Murphy <colleen@gazlene.net>

commit_message:
Use beaker-puppet_install_helper to install puppet

When running with BEAKER_provision=no, the following happens:

In Trusty: beaker is running dpkg with '--force' option so even if
Puppet is already installed, the return code will be 0.
In CentOS: beaker is running 'rpm -ivh' the second time and since the
package is already here, the return code will be 1.

Using the new puppet install helper will abort installing puppet if
BEAKER_provision is no, so tests will continue as normal.

Co-Authored-By: Colleen Murphy <colleen@gazlene.net>
Change-Id: Ifd24a24226dd23df691e43f3dc7fc379c04ae075
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/49/196249/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: unless ENV['BEAKER_provision'] == 'no' install_puppet end

Use beaker-puppet_install_helper to install puppet

When running with BEAKER_provision=no, the following happens:

In Trusty: beaker is running dpkg with '--force' option so even
if Puppet is already installed, the return code will be 0.
In CentOS: beaker is running 'rpm -ivh' the second time and since
the package is already here, the return code will be 1.

Using the new puppet install helper will abort installing puppet

commit_message:
redhat: install deltarpm before any Package

To resolve RPM's deltas, we need to install the deltarpm tool
before installing any package.

It would solve this issue:
Execution of '/usr/bin/yum -d 0 -e 0 -y install python-nova' returned 1:
Delta RPMs disabled because /usr/bin/applydeltarpm not installed.

Change-Id: I69efaf87bbcc5f233e02eb380f9d0345e2e14a6c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack_extras refs/changes/82/197782/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: command => '/usr/bin/yum clean all && /usr/bin/yum install -y applydeltarpm',

commit_message:
Enhance ShowNodeInfoDialog and dialogMixin

- Use React synthetic events to close dialogs on escape key
- Fix cursor for toggleable group headers
- Fix dialog jumping when toggling groups

Related to blueprint node-naming

Change-Id: I7040fec94907b0df794277a3a4d13ba06dafc72c

commit_message:
set default limit to meter/sample queries

this patch makes existing limit options in meter and samples apis
mandatory. if not set explicitly, a default limit will be applied.

DocImpact
ApiImpact

Change-Id: Ie354e8e64a6f8677a0be7e75c34e8901cdffbc6a
Implements: blueprint mandatory-limit
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/92/196792/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import logfrom ceilometer.i18n import _, _LILOG = log.getLogger(__name__) cfg.CONF.import_opt('default_api_return_limit', 'ceilometer.api.app', group='api') def enforce_limit(limit): """Ensure limit is defined and is valid. if not, set a default.""" if limit and limit < 0: raise base.ClientSideError(_("Limit must be positive")) if not limit: limit = cfg.CONF.api.default_api_return_limit LOG.info(_LI('No limit value provided, result set will be' 'limited to %(limit)d.'), {limit: limit}) return limit

commit_message:
Get rid of duplicated creation of security groups in test_volume_boot_pattern

It turns out that a security group in test test_volume_boot_pattern
is created twice. The first security group is created in test itself,
the second security group is created in the method _boot_instance_from_
volume(). This patch fixes it. Now the security group is created once.

Change-Id: I1c10e80161880c7ad04f7c0f48d51cc03b6cbada
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/50/198050/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def _boot_instance_from_volume(self, vol_id, keypair): self.security_group = self._create_security_group() security_groups = [{'name': self.security_group['name']}] 'security_groups': security_groups self.security_group = self._create_security_group() keypair) keypair) instance_from_snapshot = self._boot_instance_from_volume(volume['id'], keypair) def _boot_instance_from_volume(self, vol_id, keypair): bdms = [{'uuid': vol_id, 'source_type': 'volume', 'destination_type': 'volume', 'boot_index': 0, 'delete_on_termination': False}] self.security_group = self._create_security_group() security_groups = [{'name': self.security_group['name']}] create_kwargs = { 'block_device_mapping_v2': bdms, 'security_groups': security_groups

Also changed 'reverse' function location, let it be more
available for other modules.

Change-Id: Id46b533e8d2a8021d1fbb2e5d4284508e1181704
Implements: blueprint snapshot-download-with-auth
"}]
commit_message:
Snapshot download with authentication

Add new handler SnapshotDownload which returns empty response
with X-Accel-Redirect header. Nginx reads this header and
serves actuall snapshot file.

Also changed 'reverse' function location, let it be more
available for other modules.

Change-Id: Id46b533e8d2a8021d1fbb2e5d4284508e1181704
Implements: blueprint snapshot-download-with-auth

commit_message:
Add insentive to write a long description

Again, again and again, new projects are released without a long
description, which makes the lives of distribution package
maintainers miserable. This patch intends to help to fix that.

Change-Id: I9cdd9dd142153cf2d2f7d5122ed0c22f09a97ea6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-cookiecutter refs/changes/57/197357/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Please feel here a long description which must be at least 3 lines wrapped on 80 cols, so that distribution package maintainers can use it in their packages. Note that this is a hard requirement.

commit_message:
New ZeroMQ driver implementation details

Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/zmq-patterns-usage

This spec proposes a new zmq driver which should develop in parallel
to the existing one and should substitute the existing driver after
some stabilization period. This spec is extension of [1]
where was original proposal to implement a new zmq driver.

Existing driver implementation sticks to a universal socket pipeline approach.
This means that all messaging patterns are implemented over a single socket
pipeline.

In [1] there were proposed to develop new zmq driver and to switch from a splitted
universal forward(PUSH/PULL)+backward(PUB/SUB) pipeline to a unified REQ/REP
bidirectional pipeline. The change simplifies the driver implementation and
makes it more reliable but the pipeline still remains universal.

The main drawback of the universal pipeline is that it can not be optimized
for some specific messaging pattern. For example, if we would like to
make a FANOUT cast over a universal pipeline (PUSH/PULL or REQ/REP does not matter)
we have to emulate it over a number of direct casts while it could be
done over PUB/SUB zeromq pattern using a single api call.

This specification proposes to extend new zmq driver implementation
with several specific socket pipelines according to each messaging pattern.

1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/171131/

Change-Id: Ibb7d403f3b7fe5639345bf1540429e2b8506655a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/38/187338/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================================== ZeroMQ driver implementation details ==================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/zmq-patterns-usage This specification proposes ZeroMQ driver implementation details. This proposal may be considered as extension of [1] and further driver development road-map. Drawings and charts are presented in [2]. Problem description =================== Oslo.messaging provides a few patterns of communication between components. These patterns are CAST(FANOUT), CALL and NOTIFY. ZeroMQ driver may be implemented in several ways. Existing driver implementation sticks to a universal socket pipeline approach. This means that all messaging patterns are implemented over a single socket pipeline. In [1] there were proposed to switch from a splitted universal forward(PUSH/PULL)+backward(PUB/SUB) pipeline to a unified REQ/REP bidirectional pipeline. The change simplifies the driver implementation and makes it more reliable but the pipeline still remains universal. The main drawback of the universal pipeline is that it can not be optimized for some specific messaging pattern. For example, if we would like to make a FANOUT cast over a universal pipeline (PUSH/PULL or REQ/REP does not matter) we have to emulate it over a number of direct casts while it could be done over PUB/SUB zeromq pattern using a single api call. This specification proposes to extend zmq driver implementation with several specific socket pipelines according to each messaging pattern. Proposed change =============== ZMQ Proxy --------- The main reason to have a proxy entity between the client and server is lack of ability in zmq library to bind several sockets to a single IP port. The alternative path is to use dynamic port binding which in terms of zmq API means using of a :meth:`zmq.Socket.bind_to_random_port` method. Despite this approach seems more attractive because of its brokerlessness it has some serious pitfalls which show the proxy solution as more simple and reliable. 1. Dynamic port binding consumes more time to establish a connection. Time exceeding may happen if too many ports in a system are busy and the function needs a lot of retries. 2. Number of ports is limited to a number of 16-bit integer 2^16 = 65535. So a number of unoccupied ports may also come to the end especially for a large-scale clouds. 3. Less critical but significant complexity is a necessity to notify a client about the chosen port somehow. Such mechanism may be implemented using Redis to pass information between nodes. Time for Redis to sync tables has to be added to a connection time in 1. Here the delay may be even greater than in 1, because of the network latency. All these points makes us to give preference to a proxy solution. It also has its drawbacks, but advantages are: 1. More predictable time to establish a connection. 2. Fixed number of ports to allocate for the driver. Important point is the proxy should stay as close to the rpc-server as possible and should be considered as a part of an rpc-server. The proxy is not a central broker to run it on a separate host even if it would be some kind of a virtual host. The proxy communicates with rpc-servers over IPC protocol and shields them from TCP network. To implement the concept of a `Dedicated socket pipeline` we can use a separate proxy for each pipeline to keep them independent. Dedicated Socket Pipelines -------------------------- The main part of a change proposal which complements to [1]. The purpose is to use the most appropriate zmq pattern for oslo.messaging pattern implementation. 1. REQ/REP (ROUTER/DEALER) for CALL In [1] spec there was proposed to use a socket pipeline built over REQ/REP. We do not change our mind here and keep this pipeline, but use it only for CALL pattern purposes. 2. PUB/SUB for FANOUT CAST The nice thing in zmq is possibility to publish to `tcp://*:port` and subscribing to a specific topic. This is exactly what is needed to implement FANOUT CAST. We can also do a direct CAST over this pipeline publishing to a specific target instead of `*`. So, number 3 is optional. 3. PUSH/PULL for direct CAST As mentioned above this is optional, but PUSH/PULL is exact pattern for direct CAST, so should be the most optimal. 4. PUB/SUB for Notifier The PUB/SUB zeromq pattern well suited for Notifier implementation. In order to keep socket pipelines as well as messaging patterns implementation independent from each other we need to make this in a separate pipeline in spite of 2 also uses PUB/SUB. Notifier is not as widely used as an RPC (1-3), so this item may be optionally implemented in next iterations. Ceilometer seems to be the main client of the pattern. Redis ----- Current implementation of zmq driver uses Redis to pass host+topic linkage between nodes. In paragraphs above there was specified that PUB/SUB filtering attempts to resolve this problem. If PUB/SUB would not be enough for FANOUT implementation we can reuse the solution with Redis. Redis is a great in-memory distributed storage but zmq driver should move away from external services to become self-sufficient driver. Heartbeats ---------- Heartbeats are definitely needed to find out disconnections/reconnections quickly. CALL (REQ/REP) pipeline can pass heartbeats both ways (ping-pong heartbeating), while others work only in one direction. If we accept messages with payload they are also treated as heartbeats. Heartbeats should go over the same channel as real data. We should not open a separate connection to pass heartbeats. Alternatives ------------ All things may be implemented over universal socket pipeline as described in [1]. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- None. Security impact --------------- For the sake of secure message passing some features from [3] may be used. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Configuration Impact -------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- None. Testing Impact -------------- Existing functional tests should cover this change. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ozamiatin Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: liberty-3 Work Items ---------- Modified work items from [1] - Implement CALL (REQ/REP) pipeline and surrounding modules - move message serialization, topics manipulations etc. from existing implementation to appropriate modules - rpc_client part - broker_part - rpc_server part - replies handling - Implement CAST over PUSH/PULL pipeline (client-proxy-server) - Implement FANOUT and its PUB/SUB pipeline - Implement Notifier separate PUB/SUB pipeline Incubation ========== None. Adoption -------- None. Library ------- oslo.messaging. Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- None. Documentation Impact ==================== None. Dependencies ============ None. References ========== 1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/171131/ 2. http://www.slideshare.net/davanum/oslomessaging-new-0mq-driver-proposal 3. http://rfc.zeromq.org/spec:26 .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

subject: Add user-identity-format-flexibility for oslo.log
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-29 17:34:35.000000000', 'files': ['specs/liberty/oslo.log-user-identity-format-flexibility.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs/commit/b13bb89596ec740c83f95aed7d960f0b8f81dc4e', 'message': 'Add user-identity-format-flexibility for oslo.log

Change-Id: I6608fe612dc6530dc31c51c3e3eff37ce6f97cf2
'}]
commit_message:
Add user-identity-format-flexibility for oslo.log

Change-Id: I6608fe612dc6530dc31c51c3e3eff37ce6f97cf2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/52/196752/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================== oslo.log -- ``user_identity`` format flexibility ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.log/+spec/user-identity-format-flexibility The goal of this blueprint is to make it easier to adjust the format of the ``user_identity`` field in the log line without having to specify the full log format string. Problem description =================== * We want devstack to log identity using names, but by default we want identity to use UUID values because they are guaranteed to be unique. * We don't want devstack to override the format string for projects individually. * We do want devstack to be able to change the default format without having to specify the whole string, for this leaves devstack with no info on anything added into the default formatting sting. Proposed change =============== Since oslo.context is not using oslo.config, and is incorrectly enforcing formatting, we want to make this change to oslo.log. Let oslo.log control the formatting for the user_identity value in the log output. We have to leave the value in place in oslo.context, but we don't have to use it any more. Add a new configuration option to specify how to format the user_identity field. (We might find it useful to do this for other fields in the future, too, but let's focus on one for now.) Update oslo.log so it asks oslo.context for the values, and then replaces the user_identity with a string it builds itself using values it gets from oslo.context and the format string it gets from its configuration option. Alternatives ------------ We could require anyone wanting to customize the log format to replace the entire format string, but that makes it a little harder to adjust just part of it as we standardize the overall structure of the log messages. We could place the configuration option in oslo.context, but that library is not using oslo.config yet and it should not have log formatting logic embedded in it. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- None. The :class:`RequestContext` from oslo.context will still need to provide user_identity for backwards compatibility. Security impact --------------- The result will be no more or less secure than before. Performance Impact ------------------ One extra format call should not have a big performance impact. Configuration Impact -------------------- One new configuration option, with the default set up to result in the same format we have now. Developer Impact ---------------- Users of devstack will eventually be able to see user identity in a nicer format. Testing Impact -------------- No significant change. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: doug-hellmann Other contributors: ihrachyshka Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: liberty-3 Work Items ---------- #. add a new config option to oslo.log to control how the user_identity values are formatted; default it to what oslo.context does now #. add a new method to oslo.context to provide identity values to go into that format string (or just use the whole context dict?) Dict is fine. #. update oslo.log to build a new string and update the dictionary given to it from to_dict() always #. update devstack to set the new configuration option in a way that uses names instead of, or in addition to, uuids Incubation ========== N/A Documentation Impact ==================== The new configuration option needs to be documented. Dependencies ============ - This is related to :doc:`../kilo/app-agnostic-logging-parameters` but only depends on it in the sense that only projects using oslo.log and oslo.context will be able to take advantage of the feature. References ========== - notes: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/logging-flexibility .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Enable optional dependencies in OpenStack projects

Projects wish to capture their optional dependencies - things they
need only when specific configuration options are enabled. We need to
make sure the plumbing works for this to allow them to do that.

Change-Id: Ibc80ffb11239c0ee1c2a44d40008b54480e7a681
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/30/187830/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================= Optional Dependencies ======================= Projects wish to capture their optional dependencies - things they need only when specific configuration options are enabled. We need to make sure the plumbing works for this to allow them to do that. Problem description =================== Python tooling supports 'extras' but pbr hasn't exposed it, and our tooling is unaware of it. Proposed change =============== Add extras to oslo.db exporting the various driver options it uses, and update keystone to consume those during CI. Deal with any issues, and then open the floodgates. Alternatives ------------ None Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- Folk introspecting requirements.txt will not see the optional dependencies within a project (but they wouldn't before either). Dependencies using extras can already be used (e.g. requests[security]) so this isn't new in that dimension. Security impact --------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Configuration Impact -------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- Developers need to know a little bit more about how Python packaging works, but not much. Testing Impact -------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Work Items ---------- * Raise the cap on pbr to <2.0 everywhere in master, or perhaps uncapped. * Decide whether to centralise the driver choices (e.g. postgresql) into the oslo library directly using it, or to keep them in the applications, or to export the choice from the application but centralise the implementation. Concretely, is it 'pip install nova oslo.db[mysql]' or 'pip install nova[mysql]', and should the latter case be defined as 'mysql: PyMySQL' or 'mysql: oslo.db[mysql]'. * Ensure everyone knows to use latest virtualenv packages (the requirements management spec will be driving that). * Teach update.py to update extras in setup.cfg. * Document the convention of things for test being in the 'test' extra (used via pip install -e .[test]). * Add extras to oslo.db. * Add use of those to keystone for CI. * Announce the readiness and encourage people to do this. Incubation ========== N/A. Documentation Impact ==================== We need to update some pbr docs, but thats about it AFAIK. Dependencies ============ None known. References ========== * summit session https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-oslo-optional-dependencies * oslo.db patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/184328/ .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/03/189003/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================= Integrating Kafka Messaging into oslo_messaging ================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+spec/adding-kafka-support Apache Kafka is messaging broker which enables to establish nice log-centric communication bus in OpenStack. Problem description =================== Some OpenStack service like Ceilometer or Monasca have the collaboration part with Apach Kafka, distributed messaging system, to publish and subscribe logging data. These services have nice communication with kafka service, and also it will be expected to appear the new kafaka related implementation in existing or future OpenStack project. This blueprint aims to implement kafka publisher and subscriber in oslo_messaging to make log-centric communication support, and can reduce the wasting time for next developers to reimplemant the same functionality. Proposed change =============== To reduce the cost of implementing kafka communication functinality independently, oslo_messaging has to provide the kafka subscriber/publisher supports. Kafka is not expected to be used as a RPC broker, this means the functions of kafka is not conflict with existing RPC codes, adding the support like oslo_messaging.kafka_service. Alternatives ------------ There are several messaging brokers currently not supported by oslo_messaging, for example NATS, NSQ and etc. However, kafka have status to be used more than one projects and also it would be expected to collabolate with kafka for the future projects. Also, Kafka have several functionality which is better for logging data. For example, Kafka queue retaines the messages for configured period of time. This means that when consumers of the queue lost messages after subscribing, they can replay the same message. Also horizontal scaling of kafka is easy to be done thanks to Zookeeper. This means additinal kafka brokers and consumers are easily joined. Moreover, kafka can send the bunch of messages together, this can contribute the performance and flexibility of messaging. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- None Security impact --------------- Current security support of Kafka are unter implementaion. Authentication of clients and ecrypting connections would be comming. More information can be found in the references. Performance Impact ------------------ There would be no impact unless the kafka is selected for use. The overall performance will depend on the server component which the broker is setted up. The paper related to Kafka says that producers can publish about 50,000 messages/sec on the condition that message size is 200 byte and messages are sent one by one. However, this number is affected by parameters such as message size, the number of replication, batch size (kafka can send multiple messages together), and environments. Roughly, RabbitMQ can publish about 10,000 messages/sec, it means kafka might not be the bottleneck of performance. Configuration Impact -------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Testing Impact -------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <kshimamu> Other contributors: <yudupi> <dedutta> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Kilo Work Items ---------- * Making Kafka publisher/subscriber into oslo_messaging Incubation ========== None Adoption -------- Ceilometer and Monasca have Kafka use cases. Ceilomter project will get Kafka publisher as a metrics publisher, and monasca project is using kafka as a part of their architecture. Library ------- oslo_messaging Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- None Documentation Impact ==================== Need to add the chapter which menthions about the logging-centric messaging supports using Kafka and function explanations witch would be implemented in oslo_messaging.kafka_service. Dependencies ============ Kafka python package * https://pypi.python.org/pypi/kafka-python References ========== Apache Kafka Project * http://kafka.apache.org/ Kafka: a Distributed Messaging System for Log Processing * http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/um/people/srikanth/netdb11/netdb11papers/netdb11-final12.pdf Kafka Security * https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Security KAFKA 0.8 PRODUCER PERFORMANCE * http://blog.liveramp.com/2013/04/08/kafka-0-8-producer-performance-2/ Performance of Kafka * http://kafka.apache.org/07/performance.html RabbitMQ Performance Benchmarks * http://blogs.vmware.com/vfabric/2013/04/how-fast-is-a-rabbit-basic-rabbitmq-performance-benchmarks.html Comparison of Messaging Queues * http://www.bravenewgeek.com/dissecting-message-queues/ .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Add documentation for cross-project unit testing

Change-Id: I4270af00b14d33a66439fa8d7141c192df1f0c3a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslotest refs/changes/50/197050/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================ Cross-project Unit Testing ============================ Libraries in OpenStack have an unusual ability to introduce breaking changes. All of the projects are run together from source in one form or another during the integration tests, but they are not combined from source when unit tests are run. The server applications do not generally import code from other projects, so their unit tests are isolated. The libraries, however, are fundamentally intended to be used during unit tests as well as integration tests. Testing the full cross-product of libraries and consuming projects would consume all available test servers, and so we cannot run all of the tests on all patches to the libraries. As an alternative, we have a few scripts in ``oslotest`` for running the unit tests in serial. The result takes far too long (usually overnight) to run in the OpenStack infrastructure. Instead, they are usually run by hand on a dedicated system. A cloud VM works well for this purpose, especially considering how much of it is now automated. Check Out OpenStack Source ========================== The first step for all of the cross-project unit tests tools is to ensure that you have a full copy of the OpenStack source checked out. You can do this yourself through gerrit's ssh API, or you can use the ``clone_openstack.sh`` command in the tools directory of the ``openstack/oslo-incubator`` repository. For example:: $ mkdir -p ~/repos/openstack $ cd ~/repos/openstack $ git clone git://git.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-incubator $ cd ~/repos $ ./openstack/oslo-incubator/tools/clone_openstack.sh The first time the script runs it will take quite some time, since it has to download the entire history of every OpenStack project. Testing One Project =================== ``oslo_run_cross_tests`` runs one set of unit tests for one library against all of the consuming projects. It should be run from the directory with the library to be tested, and passed arguments telling it about another project whose tests should be run. For example, to run the ``py27`` test suite from nova using the currently checked out sources for ``oslo.config``, run:: $ cd ~/repos/openstack/oslo.config $ tox -e venv -- oslo_run_cross_tests ~/repos/openstack/nova py27 Testing All Consumers ===================== ``oslo_run_pre_release_tests`` builds on ``oslo_run_cross_tests`` to find all of the consuming projects and run their tests automatically. The pre-release script needs to know where the source has been checked out, so the first step is to create its configuration file. Edit ``~/.oslo.conf`` to contain:: [DEFAULT] repo_root = /path/to/repos Replace ``/path/to/repos`` with the full, expanded, absolute path to the location where the source code was checked out. For example, if you followed the instructions above using ``clone_openstack.sh`` in ``~/repos`` and your user name is ``theuser`` the path would be ``/home/theuser/repos``. Returning to the earlier example, to test ``oslo.config`` with all of the projects that use it, go to the ``oslo.config`` source directory and run ``oslo_run_pre_release_tests``. :: $ cd ~/repos/openstack/oslo.config $ tox -e venv -- oslo_run_pre_release_tests The output for each test set is logged to a separate file in the current directory, to make them easy to examine. Use the ``--update`` or ``-u`` option to force a ``git pull`` for each consuming projects before running its tests (useful for maintaining a long-running system to host these tests). Use the ``--verbose`` or ``-v`` option to report more verbosely about what is happening, including the number of projects being tested. Use ``--env`` or ``-e`` to add a tox environment to test. By default the ``py27`` and ``pep8`` environments are used because those have been shown to provide a good balance between finding problems and running the tests quickly. Use the ``--ref`` option to test a specific commit reference of the library under test. The default is to leave the source directory untouched, but if this option is specified ``git checkout`` is used to force the source tree to the specified reference.

commit_message:
Make live migration create a migration object record

The object is terminally updated based on whether the driver calls
the success or failure callback, which should be when things have
completely finished and properly reflect the driver's notion of
success.

Related to blueprint robustify-live-migration

Change-Id: I515ab9d67eb205fe171078826e69d1016ab3ebda

commit_message:
Change /dump url to internal in nginx conf

/dump is used for snapshot downloading - since we want to allow
only authenticated users, we change the url to /api/dump/
(which is handled by nailgun and authentication occurs).
Then user is redirected to /dump (using XSendfile).
To prevent potential intruder from downloading sensitive data
/dump should be changed to 'internal'.

Change-Id: I1ee2758e3f21803c82c3587e706f46877fcfbe9b
Implements: blueprint snapshot-download-with-auth
Depends-On: Id46b533e8d2a8021d1fbb2e5d4284508e1181704

commit_message:
Attach auth token to snapshot download request

* chunked download of snapshot
* add X-Auth-Token header to get request
* change urllib2 to requests

Change-Id: Ic2a3073a8a377e99ddf1cf97a9934dab9257d302
Implements: blueprint snapshot-download-with-auth
Depends-On: Id46b533e8d2a8021d1fbb2e5d4284508e1181704
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/63/195963/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import requestsdef save_logs(url, path, auth_token=None, chunk_size=1024): logger.info('Saving logs to "{}" file'.format(path)) headers = {} if auth_token is not None: headers['X-Auth-Token'] = auth_token stream = requests.get(url, headers=headers, stream=True) if stream.status_code != 200: logger.error("%s %s: %s", stream.status_code, stream.reason, stream.content) return with open(path, 'wb') as fp: for chunk in stream.iter_content(chunk_size=chunk_size): if chunk: fp.write(chunk) fp.flush() save_logs(url, os.path.join(settings.LOGS_DIR, log_file_name), auth_token=env.fuel_web.client.client.token)
deleted_lines: import urllib2def save_logs(url, filename): logger.info('Saving logs to "{}" file'.format(filename)) try: with open(filename, 'w') as f: f.write( urllib2.urlopen(url).read() ) except (urllib2.HTTPError, urllib2.URLError) as e: logger.error(e) save_logs(url, os.path.join(settings.LOGS_DIR, log_file_name))

commit_message:
Fix _check_action_complete method to wait for object status change

Currently when deleting a node, senlin excepts the physical object
to change to DELETE_IN_PROGRESS very fast, but physical needs a
little time to change the status. So when the physical object is
not changing yet, return False back instead of raising an exception.

Change-Id: I724b77f6973e26e904f23e795f2aca2a90023de7
Closes-Bug: #1469953
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/47/196947/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Wait for physical object to change status. scheduler.sleep(1)

commit_message:
Add some random strings to create nova server name

Currently when creating a nova instance node, instance
name is the same with node name, as heat stack name
has been changed to be different from node name, server
name should also be changed to keep consistency.

Change-Id: I4f5ca77fc8436621af4bc203a70a0bf20166e36f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/09/197809/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import random import string random_str = '-' + ''.join(random.choice(string.ascii_lowercase) for i in range(8)) kwargs[self.NAME] = obj.name + random_str

commit_message:
carbonara: add a serializable mixin

This allows to serialize other timeseries other than the
TimeSerieArchive.

Change-Id: I699d4c5e357d64b57f71cf8f6a9fe11c89d914f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/96/195096/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class SerializableMixin(object): @classmethod def unserialize(cls, data): return cls.from_dict(msgpack.loads(data, encoding='utf-8')) @classmethod def unserialize_from_file(cls, stream): return cls.from_dict(msgpack.unpack(stream, encoding='utf-8')) def serialize(self): return msgpack.dumps(self.to_dict()) def serialize_to_file(self, stream): return msgpack.pack(self.to_dict(), stream) class TimeSerie(SerializableMixin):class TimeSerieArchive(SerializableMixin):
deleted_lines: class TimeSerie(object):class TimeSerieArchive(object): @classmethod def unserialize(cls, data): return cls.from_dict(msgpack.loads(data, encoding='utf-8')) @classmethod def unserialize_from_file(cls, stream): return cls.from_dict(msgpack.unpack(stream, encoding='utf-8')) def serialize(self): return msgpack.dumps(self.to_dict()) def serialize_to_file(self, stream): return msgpack.pack(self.to_dict(), stream)

commit_message:
Support flavor object in migrate_disk_and_power_off

I11a28cd3b2eb98b42d78f9327ed6b38dc2bc8f30 makes resize rpc api to send flavor
object, so that we can use flavor object in migrate_disk_and_power_off().

Related to blueprint liberty-objects

Change-Id: If5368d3f15fea4157e5331349d818335514c83e3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/86/192786/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: new_root_gb = flavor.root_gb

Refactor network API 'get_instance_nw_info' in order to refresh
the instance nw_info cache and fulfill system metadata for neutron
and nova-network. Work together with 'refresh_cache' synchronous
lock so that avoiding to update nw_info cache to empty list from
network change event during booting instance.

Race: instance nw_info cache is updated to empty list because of
nova/neutron event mechanism when booting instance with port id.

Refactor network API 'get_instance_nw_info' in order to refresh
the instance nw_info cache and fulfill system metadata for neutron
and nova-network. Work together with 'refresh_cache' synchronous
lock so that avoiding to update nw_info cache to empty list from
network change event during booting instance.

Closes-Bug: #1407664

commit_message:
Refactor network API 'get_instance_nw_info'

Refactor network API 'get_instance_nw_info' for
neutron and nova-network. Rewrite the common logic
in the base function of network.base_api,
and create an interface '_get_instance_nw_info'
so that subclass can implemented it.

Change-Id: I8f8d2db5a0a1180e4aada34c3aade855d9314611
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/36/146036/47 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._get_instance_nw_info(context, instance)

commit_message:
Fix error msg on "Settings->VMware" tab

Fix error msg "Invalid Network Interface" to "Invalid network interface"
as well as error messages mentioned in comments to Patch-Set-1. Also
fixed error msgs on couple other lines in the same file.

Change-Id: I87b5cc8794e59bde8a61f3cf269fbcb386835ceb
DocImpact:
Closes-Bug: #1457903
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/28/198028/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: error: "Invalid network interface"

subject: Allow gnocchi API at /metric
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-24 15:33:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/e026f651c027025f864770d70d1bd8733861a6a4', 'message': "Allow gnocchi API at /gnocchi

One of the devstack goals is to get all the services running at
endpoints that are under the same host and port, for example:

   http://api.example.com/gnocchi
   http://api.example.com/ceilometer
   http://api.example.com/keystone

This changeset enables that.

GNOCCHI_SERVICE_PREFIX defaults to /gnocchi

The service will run at:

* GNOCCHI_SERVICE_PORT (8041) at /v1/...
* port 80 at /gnocchi/v1/...

and the official keystone endpoint will be the port 80 based URL.

The gabbi-based live test will use prefix if it is provided (but will fail
until a bug in gabbi is fixed).

There's additional work to do here to get things fully aligned with
the goals but this gets things moving in the right direction. A next
step is for the wsgi script to not require explicit installation.

Change-Id: Iec2924b5460afe2ebeafab7c82eb4ddf184f2c99
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-25 09:03:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/dac57c736a7d9896eeb7c1a94644c85dd8612b42', 'message': "Allow gnocchi API at /gnocchi

One of the devstack goals is to get all the services running at
endpoints that are under the same host and port, for example:

   http://api.example.com/metric
   http://api.example.com/telemetry
   http://api.example.com/identity

This changeset enables that.

GNOCCHI_SERVICE_PREFIX defaults to /metric

The service will by default run on port 80 at /metric/v1/...

If GNOCCHI_SERVICE_PORT is defined (undefined by default) the server
will run without a prefix, on the stated port.

The gabbi-based live test will use prefix if it is provided.

There's additional work to do here to get things fully aligned with
the goals but this gets things moving in the right direction. A next
step is for the wsgi script to not require explicit installation.

Change-Id: Iec2924b5460afe2ebeafab7c82eb4ddf184f2c99

commit_message:
Allow gnocchi API at /metric

One of the devstack goals is to get all the services running at
endpoints that are under the same host and port, for example:

   http://api.example.com/metric
   http://api.example.com/telemetry
   http://api.example.com/identity

This changeset enables that.

GNOCCHI_SERVICE_PREFIX defaults to /metric

The service will by default run on port 80 at /metric/v1/...

If GNOCCHI_SERVICE_PORT is defined (undefined by default) the server
will run without a prefix, on the stated port.

The gabbi-based live test will use the server addressed by
GNOCCHI_SERVICE_URL. If that is not set, the live test won't run.

There's additional work to do here to get things fully aligned with
the goals but this gets things moving in the right direction. One of
the next steps is for the wsgi script to not require explicit
installation from the devstack plugin. Ideally the pip install
process would accomplish this.

Change-Id: Iec2924b5460afe2ebeafab7c82eb4ddf184f2c99
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/49/195149/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: prefix = os.getenv('GNOCCHI_SERVICE_PREFIX') if prefix: port = None host=host, prefix=prefix, port=port)

commit_message:
Drop the Enum for vip_types to allow for more vip allocations

vip_types is forced into an Enum, but this prevents allocating more
addresses when seperating components.

Partial blueprint: detach-components-from-controllers

Change-Id: Icbff48cde56a781c99f5a5e7f09c314543ee96fe

commit_message:
Corrections to WEBROOT docs.

1) Misspelling of 'dashboard'
2) Exclusion of WSGIScriptAlias instruction for Apache
3) Inclusion of reminder to use collectstatic/compress after
   changing _variables.css
4) Capitalization of 'Apache'

Change-Id: I33c2121529ec45f8500b102e0d5979157e3e56b6
Closes-Bug: 1470982

commit_message:
Fixed experimental job for Nova API services under Apache2

If variable API_WORKERS equals 0 Apache will fail because count
of processes can not be equal 0. Added default value for API_WORKERS.

Change-Id: I898bc5980184e83f9e4b23facbdc03627fe90f6d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/62/193962/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ $API_WORKERS -eq 0 ]]; then NOVA_API_WORKERS=5 else NOVA_API_WORKERS=$API_WORKERS fi s|%APIWORKERS%|$NOVA_API_WORKERS|g s|%APIWORKERS%|$NOVA_API_WORKERS|g iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT osapi_compute_workers "$NOVA_API_WORKERS" iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT ec2_workers "$NOVA_API_WORKERS" iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT metadata_workers "$NOVA_API_WORKERS"
deleted_lines: s|%APIWORKERS%|$API_WORKERS|g s|%APIWORKERS%|$API_WORKERS|g iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT osapi_compute_workers "$API_WORKERS" iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT ec2_workers "$API_WORKERS" iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT metadata_workers "$API_WORKERS"

commit_message:
fuel-migrate script

It is made for move fuel-master from host into VM. Script is performed
on fuelmaster itself and make working clone on any kvm hipervisor

Change-Id: I4fe130ad1405bf4c1a9f8f3aa5dd21b81a86b1fa
Related-Blueprint: reduced-footprint
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/60/194060/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #fuel-migrate install -m 0755 %{files_source}/fuel-migrate/fuel-migrate %{buildroot}/usr/bin/fuel-migrate %package -n fuel-migrate Summary: Fuel migrate utility Version: %{version} Release: %{release} Group: System Environment/Libraries # FIXME(aglarendil): mixed license actually - need to figure out the best option License: Apache 2.0 URL: http://github.com/stackforge/fuel-library BuildArch: noarch Requires: dbus Requires: dbus-python Requires: pygobject2 Requires: python-daemon BuildRoot: %{_tmppath}/fuel-library-%{version}-%{release} %description -n fuel-migrate Script for migrate Fuel master into vm %files -n fuel-migrate %defattr(-,root,root) /usr/bin/fuel-migrate #

commit_message:
Add networking-arista to Neutron

This patch proposes that Neutron embrace networking-arista in
its fold. This is according to the procedure specified in [1].
networking-arista implements neutron support for various
Arista products.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/doc/source/devref/sub_projects.rst

Change-Id: I84825adc3f7beba8dd457ddb70b112e0dd2c39dc

added_lines: Retrieve and install CloudKitty:Install a sample configuration file:Start the API and processing services: Horizon integration =================== Retrieve and install CloudKitty's dashboard: :: git clone git://git.openstack.org/stackforge/cloudkitty-dashboard cd cloudkitty-dashboard python setup.py install Find where the python packages are installed, this can be done with: :: PY_PACKAGES_PATH=`pip --version | cut -d' ' -f4` Then add the enabled file the horizon settings or installation, depending on your setup, you might need to add it to /usr/share or directly in horizon python package: :: # If horizon is installed by packages: ln -s $PY_PACKAGES_PATH/cloudkittydashboard/_90_enable_ck.py \ /usr/share/openstack-dashboard/openstack_dashboard/enabled/_90_enable_ck.py # Directly from sources: ln -s $PY_PACKAGES_PATH/cloudkittydashboard/_90_enable_ck.py \ $PY_PACKAGES_PATH/openstack_dashboard/enabled/_90_enable_ck.py Restart the web server hosting Horizon and you're set.
deleted_lines: Retrieve and install CloudKitty :Install a sample configuration file :Start the API and processing services :

commit_message:
Separate image building manager

* to do not keep enormous classes separated managers code responsible
  for image building into ImageBuildManager
* added common attributes for every data driver since each manager use it
* separated tests for managers
* test for accepting different managers in CLI

Change-Id: I79a5efae5bff1db11e8757d37f82138269f9e734
Implements: blueprint volume-manager-refactoring

Add new repo puppet-openstack-integration

This repo will be the home for scripts and manifests for functional and
integration testing of the OpenStack Puppet Modules.

commit_message:
Add new oslo project

We have a new oslo.reports project under the Oslo program. This
houses the openstack/common/reports/ module under oslo-incubator.

commit_message:
Configurable memcached connections limit & threads

Increasing memcached_connections may require ulimit to be raised so
that will be done if necessary.

Increasing memcached_threads is not strongly recommended but is
available if needed.

Closes-Bug: #1438498
(cherry picked from commit d0127d51bdb9a6b51fec5d91f2dbd72177e4c4ca)

Conflicts:
	playbooks/roles/memcached_server/defaults/main.yml
	playbooks/roles/memcached_server/templates/memcached.conf
	rpc_deployment/roles/memcached/tasks/main.yml

Change-Id: I6e624f49f2fe5c6865968a01927dfa9861c945ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/40/197740/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: -c {{ memcached_connections }} -t {{ memcached_threads }}

commit_message:
Update alarm history only if change in alarm property

When alarm's property is updated with the same
value, an empty record is added to the alarm
history output.

This fix omits the update to alarm history if
there no changes to any alarm property.

Change-Id: Ib860f371979896c7eedd41a25c3b640bb6dbee31
Closes-Bug: 1465550

commit_message:
Add a new crypt method using cryptography

This updates the default crypt method to use the cryptography module
instead of the oslo crypto utils module. It also refactors decrypt to
remove some duplication.

Change-Id: Ie24aebcb3080725c250a4f3ba726b23a9c995965
Closes-Bug: #1468025

commit_message:
Add flavor tables to API database

Cellsv2 need to store flavor information for booting an instance. Since this
information will live at the cell API, tables related to flavors need to be
created in API DB.

bp flavor-cell-api

Change-Id: I10f5cf8eb8a8556b7cd22cd382f4be5ec0b05aec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/47/190147/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Add Flavor tables to API Database ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/flavor-cell-api Cellsv2 need to store flavor information for booting an instance. Since this information will live at the cell API, tables related to flavors need to be created in API DB. Problem description =================== Flavors are virtual hardware templates, which are used by nova, for example, when creating a new instance. In cellsV1, flavors are stored in parent and child cells. Considerable manual effort is required to keep this information consistent across all the cells. Flavors are a global concept that should be stored only in one database. Therefore, flavor related tables for CellsV2 would be created only in the API database. Use Cases ---------- * Operators want to partition their deployments into cells for scaling, failure domain, and buildout reasons. When partitioned, flavor information needs to be stored at API level. Project Priority ----------------- Nova Cell v2 is a project priority in liberty. Proposed change =============== With this spec we propose to create all flavor related tables in the api cell: * instance_types * instance_type_extra_specs * instance_type_projects The table schema will and the flavor object will be the same as in Cellsv1. Also, for the transition phase, tests will be written to make sure that the flavors tables in Cellsv2 have the same model as in Cellv1. Any change in the tables should be applied in both databases. Migration of data to the new tables will be handled in a different spec. Alternatives ------------ We could continue storing flavor at both api and cell level or store flavors only at compute cell level. Both these approaches introduce addtional complexity in flavor management. Data model impact ----------------- Three new tables will be created in 'nova_api' database as follows. The corresponding schema is also detailed below each, * 'instance_types'::: CREATE TABLE `instance_types` ( `created_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `updated_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `deleted_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `name` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL, `id` int(11) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, `memory_mb` int(11) NOT NULL, `vcpus` int(11) NOT NULL, `swap` int(11) NOT NULL, `vcpu_weight` int(11) DEFAULT NULL, `flavorid` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL, `rxtx_factor` float DEFAULT NULL, `root_gb` int(11) DEFAULT NULL, `ephemeral_gb` int(11) DEFAULT NULL, `disabled` tinyint(1) DEFAULT NULL, `is_public` tinyint(1) DEFAULT NULL, `deleted` int(11) DEFAULT NULL) This table will have unique constraints on (name, deleted) and (flavorid, deleted) attributes * 'instance_types_extra_specs'::: CREATE TABLE `instance_type_extra_specs` ( `created_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `updated_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `deleted_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `id` int(11) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, `instance_type_id` int(11) NOT NULL, `key` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL, `value` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL, `deleted` int(11) DEFAULT NULL) This table will have a unique constraint on (instance_type_id, key, deleted) attribute and an index on (instance_type_id, key) * 'instance_type_projects'::: CREATE TABLE `instance_type_projects` ( `created_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `updated_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `deleted_at` datetime DEFAULT NULL, `id` int(11) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, `instance_type_id` int(11) NOT NULL, `project_id` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL, `deleted` int(11) DEFAULT NULL) This table will have a unique constraint on (instance_type_id, project_id, deleted) attribute REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mvineetmenon Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Create new database tables, 'instance_types', 'instance_type_extra_specs' and 'instance_type_projects'. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Since this is designed to be an internal re-architecting of Nova with no user visible changes the current suite of Tempest or functional tests should suffice. Also, tests need to be written to ensure that the data model doesn't change from what is being used in the cellV1 model. These tests should be kept until the final migration to cellsV2. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== ``https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-nova-cells``

commit_message:
Make some exceptions Senlin internal errors

Senlin internal errors/exceptions are to be inherited from
InternalError, instead of from SenlinException directly. This will make
the exception space easier to manage.

Change-Id: I2cf15deada838a0c7c397f7344c15d5826e36960
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/43/198243/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class InternalError(SenlinException): '''A base class for internal exceptions in senlin. The internal exception classes which inherit from InternalError class should be translated to a user facing exception. ''' def __init__(self, **kwargs): super(InternalError, self).__init__(**kwargs) class ResourceBusyError(InternalError): msg_fmt = _("The %(resource_type)s (%(resource_id)s) is busy now.") class UserNotFound(InternalError):class TrustNotFound(InternalError):class ResourceNotFound(InternalError):class ResourceStatusError(InternalError): msg_fmt = _("The resource %(resource_id)s is in error status " "- '%(status)s' due to '%(reason)s'.") class PolicyNotAttached(InternalError): msg_fmt = _("The policy (%(policy)s) is not attached to the specified " "cluster (%(cluster)s).")

commit_message:
Relocate test modules

This patch moves some engine related patches to a dedicated subdir and
the engine service test cases to yet another level of subdir. It is an
attempt to avoid confusion on finding test cases.

Change-Id: I636fb99dd95f6af9ffedef1eea0ec207512e7f26

commit_message:
Extending Karma config

This patch extends karma's config to cover code in
/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/
where plugins should reside.

Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson <tyr@hp.com>

Change-Id: I82d7463f64b26bb36c2182488e20d41f1b2d87dd
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-instances-table

commit_message:
drop deprecated pipeline

the old pipeline format was deprecated as of icehouse. this patch
switches all tests to use current pipeline format and drops support
for old pipeline.

Change-Id: Ide53c1c5beab4a586324c4727dba3a9e200f8082

In the bug report, creating an endpoint with "tenant_i d" in any of
its URLs (internal, public, or admin/auth) allegedly prevented the
endpoint from being deleted.

This addition to another test case adds a space to all 3 URLs of an
endpoint.  It then gets the amount of current endpoints, deletes the
endpoint, and makes sure there is one less endpoint after attempting
to delete.

Closes-Bug: #1098564
'}]
commit_message:
Add test case for deleting endpoint with space in url

In the bug report, creating an endpoint with "tenant_i d" in any of
its URLs (internal, public, or admin) allegedly prevented the
endpoint from being deleted.

This test case adds a space to all 3 URLs of an endpoint. It then
deletes this endpoint and attempts to get it. If the get returns
error 404, then it works.

Change-Id: I0cad2410a150fb6967fc5048ebbf00b9b08efcc7
Closes-Bug: #1098564
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/83/196883/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: v2_id = endpoint_v2['id'] v3_id = endpoint_v3['id'] self.assertNotEqual(v2_id, v3_id) # test for bug 1098564 -- endpoint didn't delete with a space in a url # add a space to all urls url_with_space = "http://127.0.0.1:8774 /v1.1/\$(tenant_i d)s" ref['publicurl'] = url_with_space ref['internalurl'] = url_with_space ref['adminurl'] = url_with_space endpoint_v3['url'] = url_with_space # get the size of the endpoint list before deleting r = self.get('/endpoints') endpoints = self.assertValidEndpointListResponse(r) length_before = len(endpoints) # delete the endpoint self.delete( '/endpoints/%(endpoint_id)s' % { 'endpoint_id': v3_id}) r = self.get('/endpoints') # make sure it was deleted properly (list should shrink by 1) endpoints = self.assertValidEndpointListResponse(r) length_after = len(endpoints) self.assertEqual(length_after, length_before - 1)

commit_message:
Remove old JSON and YAML docs syntax

This change stops generating JSON (cfn) and YAML example snippets
for resource types. These are ancient and only cause clutter in
the docs.

Change-Id: I94d3a3400f0e9ba8404c2da4364e5f9acc7dc4b2

commit_message:
Clean up bindep invocation in cache-bindep element

Invoke bindep from the bindir for its virtualenv in /usr/bindep-env,
and guard its exit code with true since its normal behavior is to
return zero only when all needed packages are already present.

While here, replace calls to tempfile with mktemp since the former
is not readily available on CentOS 6.x.

Change-Id: I926e73f305b1b54f6855cc4acf3407e91b88213a

Switch constraints proposal to use branch-git-prep

We don't have zuul-cloner installed on our proposal worker, so use
the existing branch-git-prep macro for constraints proposal jobs
instead.

Without passing -H to sudo here, subsequent builders that may use pip
or tox will fail on permission issues in $HOME/.cache.

Also, this adds deboostrap to DIB's supporting packages, as it may be
required depending on what flavor disk is being built.

Change-Id: I19957cbf3b3f97660388617dd07d2010d17409e6
"}]
commit_message:
Call sudo pip /w -H diskimage-builder-install macro

Without passing -H to sudo here, subsequent builders that may use pip
or tox will fail on permission issues in $HOME/.cache.

Also, this adds deboostrap to DIB's supporting packages, as it may be
required depending on what flavor disk is being built.

Change-Id: I19957cbf3b3f97660388617dd07d2010d17409e6

commit_message:
More fixes for NSX plugin guide

This patch:
- corrects wording replacing 'NSX' with 'NSX-mh' (multi hypervisor) in
  order to clarify to which vmware plugin this document refers to, since
  the package downladed with neutron-plugins-vmware actually contains 3
  distinct plugins
- fix some sentences for style, semantics, or grammar
- adds a clarification concerning retrieval of default transport zone
- removes section on integration of load balancing and firewall on top of
  the NSX-mh plugin, as the Neutron plug-in providing this kind of service
  has been abandoned in favour of the NSX-v plugin, not yet documented in
  openstack-manuals

Change-Id: I4365a87d3f2c6dff312e945f407c1d06a4ca13ed
Closes-Bug: #1466249
